SENT.plain: The aim of the study was to assess the long-term efficacy and safety of Infliximab therapy in the treatment of patients with BehÃ§et's disease refractory to standard immunosuppressive agents

Twenty-one patients that did not respond to corticosteroids and to at least one immunosuppressant (cyclosporin, methotrexate, azathioprine, cyclophosphamide) for the presence of ocular and/or CNS involvement were enrolled
Eighteen patients completed the study up to 54 weeks
Stable doses of prednisone (<10 mg/day) were permitted, immunosuppressants were discontinued at least 4 weeks prior baseline visit
The patients received three infusions of 5 mg/kg Infliximab (at weeks 0, 2 and 6) and then infusions of 5 mg/kg Infliximab every 8 weeks
At each visit data on clinical symptoms, response to therapy and adverse events were collected
The primary outcome of interest was to assess the clinical efficacy (total or partial recovery) of infliximab
Secondary end points were to evaluate quality of life and to monitor the safety of the drug
Eighteen patients achieved a total remission
Two patients achieved a partial remission and relapsed after 3 months from discontinuation of therapy
Infliximab was well tolerated throughout the study
A case of non-Hodgkin lymphoma was observed within 6 months
Minor side effects were headache, dizziness, tachycardia that regressed spontaneously and did not entail interruption
Anti-nuclear antibodies were not detected during the period of observation
